item.title: Airbnb Tip Fest 2000
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1500.0"] A quiet day on the fifth floor of Sants, Barcelona.[/caption]

I've come to the conclusion that if you're doing the work-travel thing, you always need to have a reliable, quiet place nearby to retreat to. Most hostels just don't offer that level of privacy, while hotels are too expensive. Coworking spaces would be great, except they cost an extra $10-$30 per day. (Except the gratis Wix Lounge in New York, but there's no privacy there to speak of.)

Aside from finding rooms to rent or sublet (which can be tricky in a foreign country), the best solution I've been able to find so far is Airbnb. (Sign up with my referral link to earn us both credit, I think!) Per day, Airbnb listings tend to be roughly on par with hostels in terms of price; per month, they're more expensive than the local rental rate, but not astronomically.1 And for the extra cost, you get your own room (often with a window and desk), one or more locals to chat with, a fantastic communication and creditibility channel, and a neat little paper trail of all the places you've been to. Plus, you get to experience life in a foregin city as a local! If you've ever been to Europe, tell me you've never walked down the twisted cobblestone streets and wondered what life was like in those arborial, patchwork buildings...

Here are a few tips for finding great Airbnb rentals:

  • Check the owner's profile first and foremost. Do they have reviews and references? Do they have photos of themselves out in the real world? Do they sound like an actual human being in their writing? Does their listing have personality?2
  • This applies to you as well! The owner can reject your request for any reason, so get some good photos, write up a friendly description, and add as many verifications as possible.
  • Does the owner have several places listed in different parts of the city? (That is, are they "playing landlord"?) Look for people renting out rooms in the same house they're living in. One, this tends to be more legal, and two, you can be sure that people who rent where they live care a whole lot more about the state of their accommodations.
  • Are some of the listing photos labeled with "Airbnb.com Verified Photo"? Listings that have these photos have been visited by an official Airbnb photographer, which gives them a bit more credibility. Stay away from listings with lots of touristy photos: you want as many good photos of the interior as possible.
  • Does the listing have House Rules? When I see House Rules, I feel more confident that I'm going to be living in an actual house with real people instead of some derelict tourist pad.
  • Are there going to be other Airbnb guests in the house? Remember: Airbnb rentals usually don't have safes, so you have to trust the people you're staying with. On your end, hosts have a paper trail; other guests do not. (On the other hand, I had a very enjoyable time with two fellow Airbnb guests during my first booking. I imagine that, on average, they're a more interesting breed of traveller than hostel dwellers, at least for mid-twenties folks such as myself!)
  • Some Airbnb listings are actually hostel listings, which becomes clear when you see a bunch of bunk beds in the photos. I highly recommend booking through an actual hostel site (HostelWorld, HostelBookers) if you want to go that route. It's not really what Airbnb is for.
  • Instead of doing meticulous research and trying to reserve the one place you like, get a list of 2-10 places you think might work for you and send a message to each of the hosts via the "Contact Me" button. Ask them a few simple questions. Is the room available during this time? Do you get your own key? The reason you want to do this is that more often than not, even when you're just reaching out to to get some information, the hosts will pre-approve you for a short period of time to expedite the booking process. This means that after everyone responds to you, you'll get your pick of several places that are a guaranteed approval. (Warning: multiple guests can be pre-approved at once, so if you get pre-approaved for a listing you like, don't dawdle!) What's more, the calendars for many listings are hopelessly out of date: even when they're marked green, there's a good chance they'll be unavailable simply because the host never bothered to update their calendar.
  • Airbnb has the ability to offer different pricing for weekly and monthly rentals, and monthly prices in particular can be drastically cheaper than daily rates. If you're traveling for a while, try moving the date slider forward a bit. Additionally, even when it looks like a city is all booked out, checking for monthly rentals might yield a few more results since those places tend to be more expensive on a daily basis. (Note that even if a place is available for monthly rental, it's by no means assured that the host will go for it. It's best to contact them and ask if the dates are available.)
  • Airbnb offers a currency conversion option by default. Don't use this. If your credit card currency differs from the local currency, you'll be hit with a 3% surcharge. On the payment screen, there's a drop-down menu for your country right above the credit card picker. Select the country that you're currently in and make sure the pricing caption in the lower-right corner doesn't say anything about currency conversion or surcharges. (I don't think you can do this in the mobile app.)
  • Although this happens rarely, hosts can cancel a reservation some days in advance. Make sure you're aware of your other options if this happens.
  • It's not a huge issue, but it's worth Googling to see if the city you're travelling to has a problem with Airbnb rentals. For example, New York (until recently?) has been pretty strict about it. You don't want to risk getting evicted because the owner never bothered to read up on the local laws!
  • Finally, be sure to leave reviews! Reviews are Airbnb's capital. It's what makes the whole thing tick. Unfortunately, judging by the number of reservations compared to the number of reviews for the average listing, it sure seems that most people don't bother. If you do it, not only will you help out your host in a big way, but you'll make it more likely for the host to leave a review for you as well.

  1. Airbnb has got me looking at rental prices in the places I'm travelling to. (Numbeo is a good site for this, though I can't speak to its accuracy.) Unfortunately, compared to local prices, daily Airbnb prices are still significantly pricier than rent. For example, in Barcelona, a cheap-ish room in a shared house can go for $35 a day, whereas if you're paying rent, you can get a flat all to yourself close to the center of town for just $30 a day, or $13 a day with roomates. (Plus utilities, internet, etc.)
  2. AKA, "how not to get scammed on Craigslist or eBay 101". Asking for hosts to show a little personality might seem a little... entitled?, but it's the most sure-fire way to tell the difference between a genuine person and someone out for a quick buck. I've always adhered to this principle when buying or selling on eBay and Craigslist and never had a problem.

item.title: State of the Union
item.content:encoded:
I'm sure bad at this blogging thing. Since I first set out in — technically, July 2013, but let's say August — I've only gotten one week into my journey before hanging up. I'd like to see if I can try again, perhaps this time with a little more success.

Right now, I'm writing this from Dublin, Ireland. In the interim, since my last entry from an actual city, I've visited Vancouver, Toronto, Montreal, Quebec City, New York, Boston, Philadelphia, Chicago, New Orleans, Austin, Los Angeles, Barcelona, Paris, London, Cornwall, Bath, Oxford, Cambridge, York, Newcastle, Edinburgh, Amsterdam, Luxembourg, Prague, Berlin, Vienna, Ljubljana, Zagreb, Split, Bologna, Modena, Milan, Florence, Rome, and Turin — plus a number of smaller towns along the way. That's more than a dozen different countries over the course of the past two years. To the person first setting out on this trip — the person who expected to arrive in London and cautiously venture to other countries only on rare occasion — this list would have been unimaginable. I was nervous. I'd never been alone in a place where the primary language wasn't English. I wasn't sure about the logistics. I didn't even know if I'd be able to tinker with my projects in peace.

But it's all worked out. I've cracked the code. With some trial and error, I've figured out how to live affordably and comfortably in different cities around the world. I've gotten a lot more bold about venturing to places where I have to resort to broken apologetic phrases in a new language. I've discovered many breathtaking sights, incredible architectural wonders, and fascinating local tastes. I've pared my belongings down to a bare minimum appropriate for most climates. I've worked in many lovely cafés, bars, and apartments. I feel like I understand so much more about the world than when I started.

On the other hand, I've also had to face certain facets of myself head-on, with uncertain results. I've learned that my impression of different cities around the world was heavily painted by my childhood imagination. The places I'd hoped would bring my soul some peace — a magical sort of quality that I faintly recall in cities like London, Barcelona, and Rome from when I was little — were found to be fairly ordinary in contrast. I've found it disheartening to overwrite so much impressionistic imagery in my head with reality — because I know those feelings will never be back. I've learned that no matter how lonely I might get at times, there is still no part of me that will seek out others for company. I've learned that I can swallow up entire months at a time and wake up on the other end a good chunk older, but with nothing to show for it. All the attributes I hated about myself as a young teen are still there, entrenched, and at this point as much a part of my personality as anything else. I've learned that there are parts of me that I constantly have to fight, lest I end up old, unfulfilled, and alone.

I've also learned that time moves quickly, and that it's easy to get stuck in a simple routine. I've developed a great, burning fear that prods me almost every waking minute. The fear of aging. The fear of death. The fear of it "being too late". Every day, I count the fractions of my age. 26 point 0. Point 25. Point 3, repeating. Every day that I'm not doing something productive — which is most days, to be honest — I feel like I'm actively destroying my potential. Other dates have been creeping into my head, too. How old is too old to live in a house with other people? How old is too old to get married? To have kids, if I decide to have them? To have a nice house, friendly neighbors, warm dinner parties? When I was in college, I half-jokingly feared that my study habits — put it off, put it off, then half-ass it on the last day — would translate in broader strokes to the rest of my life. But now I see that this was no joke. This is exactly what happens when you let a negative aspect of your personality fester for years and years.

But these dark thoughts are not a reflection on travel. My journey has neither been a negative experience nor an entirely positive one. I see it as just another page in the book of my life: many new and interesting inputs from the environment feeding into the black box of my mind, allowing me to discover new truths about the world and myself.

So that's what's going on in my head on this day, January the 31st, 2015, in the city of Dublin. And now, let's step back into the past, to Vancouver, as it was during the last few weeks of August of 2013 ...

(Technical note: from this point on, I will be posting all my blog entries on the beta-blog subdomain of my website. They will be linked from the main site, but I highly suggest reading on beta-blog instead. Eventually, the main site — hosted on Squarespace — will be removed, and the beta-blog page — hosted on Github Pages using a static site generator — will replace it. I will backport all the existing entries before I do that, and all the links should still hopefully work.)

item.title: Credit/Debit for Travel 101

Let's say you want to travel. Maybe for a while. Maybe in a bunch of different countries. You know you only have a limited supply of money, and you don't want the credit card companies to nab a large chunk of it. What do you do?

Debit

First, your debit card. Most debit cards only allow free withdrawals from their issuing bank, with all other ATMs charging as much as $3 per transaction. On top of that, if you take out money at a foreign ATM, there's usually going to be an inflated exchange fee. But! There's a wonderful, magical card that not only exchanges your currency at the market rate, but refunds all ATM fees. That card is the Charles Schwab High Yield Investor Checking Account debit card, almost unequivocally recommended by travellers everywhere. All you have to do to get one is sign up for a free account on Schwab's website. You get a checking account and a brokerage account from the deal, but you don't have to use the latter if you don't want to. There are no annual fees; your refunds show up in your checking account at the end of each month. (Schwab says that you can contact them for a manual refund if they don't catch an ATM transaction, but that hasn't happened to me yet.) Even better, Schwab has one of the best banking websites I've ever seen, and they even allow interbank ACH transfers1 with no additional fees.

After several months of using my Schwab card across the US and Canada, it has become one of the most invaluable tools in my arsenal. When you're low on cash, it's incredibly liberating to be able to use any ratty ATM without having to worry about additional charges. Better yet, my exchange rate in Canada was always a fair $19 USD to $20 CAD, which is almost exactly the rate given by Google. I don't know what I'd do without this card!

Credit

Next, you should probably get a credit card or two. This one's a little more complicated.

For purchases abroad, credit cards are among the best options available. Most cards only have a 3% foreign transaction fee (1% from VISA, plus whatever the bank wants to charge), compared to 10% or more with more traditional methods like traveller's checks. There are even a few credit cards available with 0% fees. (From what I understand, 0% means that the bank actually pays VISA for letting you use their card!) This is the first feature you be looking at, since even 3% overhead could mean hundreds of dollars wasted down the line, depending on how long you'll be travelling for.

The second important feature is EMV (chip) functionality. In contrast to the magnetic stripe cards that are prevalent in the US, many countries in Europe have switched to chipped cards as an added measure of security. Although most businesses outside the US will still gladly swipe your card, it's becoming less and less of a guarantee. In addition, many unmanned vending machiens and kiosks in Europe are only able to accept chipped cards — not even cash! Even if you decide to go with a magnetic stripe card as your primary card, you'll probably want to have a chipped card as a backup.

There are two kinds of chipped cards: chip-and-pin and chip-and-signature. Out of the two, chip-and-pin cards are by far the most common abroad. To use one, you stick it into a slot on the bottom of the credit card terminal, enter your PIN, and hit enter. Chip-and-signature cards go in the same slot, but they don't have a PIN; instead, they make the machine print out a receipt for you to sign, just like with an ordinary swipe card. There are notable downsides to going with chip-and-signature over chip-and-pin: many automated kiosks in Europe only accept chip-and-pin cards, and merchants aren't used to dealing with the printed receipt from chip-and-signature transactions. Nonetheless, having a chip-and-signature card is still better than having no chipped card at all.

As a recent data point, chipped cards have become standard even up in Canada. When I visited last month, I barely ever saw anyone swipe their card.2 The card I used was chip-and-signature, and practically every merchant I met did a double-take when the second receipt printed out. I eventually resorted to asking ahead of time whether my signature was needed, since inevitably the merchat would run after me with a pen if I didn't. (And even when I asked, some of them still said "no" before being surprised by the sudden appareance of the second receipt!)

There is a growing number of EMV cards available in the US. Here's a spreadsheet with a wealth of information about pretty much every single one, courtesy of the FlyerTalk forums.

As you can see, chip-and-pin cards are still quite rare, but it's not too hard to get one. There are currently three credit unions in the US that offer chip-and-pin functionality and 0% fees: Andrews, State Department, and PenFed. Their cards are all very similar. For example, they all simultaneously have chip-and-pin and chip-and-signature technolgoy, defaulting to signature; meaning, they'll only resort to asking for your PIN if they have no choice, such as at an unmanned kiosk. You can join Andrews and State Department once you've joined the American Consumer Council, which is free and easy to do online. For PenFed, you can apparently make a donation to join, but I haven't investigated.

There are two more features in a credit card that are very useful for a traveler: VISA Signature, and rewards programs. With a VISA Signature card, you get a wide variety of complementary services, including automatic extended warranties, lost luggage coverage, rental auto insurance, concierge service, and more. Credit card rewards programs give you back a percentage of your purchases, usually 1%—3% in either cash-back or proprietary points. Some points can only be exchanged for specific things (Hilton stays) while others are more generic and can be used on Amazon or exchanged for gift cards. Many credit cards also offer hefty signup bonuses that can reach $300 or more. If you have a good credit rating and are responsible with your payments, that's basically free money!3

If you're thinking of getting a chip-and-pin card, the Andrews Federal Credit Union GlobeTrek VISA is a good option. It's one of the oldest chip-and-pin cards in the US, and as such, has been vetted by a large number of international travellers. Unfortunately, Andrews' banking website still leaves much to be desired, and the application process was a bit arduous when I applied.4 There are also a few quirks with day-to-day usage of this card, though I don't know if it's an issue with Andrews in particular or if all credit unions have similar problems.5 With that said, they recently updated their website, and I imagine they have a lot of pressure to improve as one of the most popular chip-and-pin options for travellers.

For your everyday spending credit card, you might want to take a look at the Citibank ThankYou Premier or the Chase Sapphire Preferred. Both have 0% foreign transaction fees, though they do charge an annual fee that's waived for the first year. Both have pretty good signup rewards: ~$200 for Citi and ~$350 for Chase. Both cards are VISA Signature cards, and both offer chip-and-signature support. If you don't want to bother with the annual fee, the CapitalOne Cash Rewards is a great card with no fees, VISA Signature, and a [] bonus. You can find updated lists of no-fee cards, along with reviews, at websites like [] and [].

For redundancy, it might be a good idea to pack at least two debit and two credit cards. Some ATM machines have been known to eat debit cards in case of an error, and credit card companies are notorious for cutting you off at even the slightest hint of fraud. You don't want to get stuck without any money halfway across the world!

Conclusion: debt might be bad and banks might be crooked, but you would be wise to use the financial resources available to you.

  1. There are several ways of transfering money between banks in the US: ACH transfers, wire transfers, and checks. Both ACH transfers and wire transfers are elctronic. ACH transfers take a few days to clear, while wire transfers are instantaneous. On the downside, pretty much every bank charges about $20 per wire transfer. ↩
  2. For the record, it's no crime to sign up for a credit card for the reward and then cancel once your free year is up. In fact, there are communities out there that "churn" thorugh large numbers of credit cards every year in order to maximize the amount of points they get! Despite what you may think, this is unlikely to lower your credit score, and in fact will probably raise it in the long run. The only catch is that you have to pay off your bills every month, never go into debt, and only go on a churning spree once every few months. ↩
  3. Many of these terminals were also battery-powered and wireless, meaning that waiters usually brought them to your table instead of whisking your card away. There were even buttons to automatically add the tip. Really neat stuff! ↩
  4. Here's how the application process went down:
    1. I applied for a free membership at the American Consumer Council and got a membership number by e-mail right away.
    2. I went to the credit card application site and filled out the online form. They had a checkmark for whether you already had a checking/savings account at Andrews, so I assumed they would create one for me automatically. Oops.
    3. A day or two later, Andrews called me to confirm my application and asked me to send over some pay stubs.
    4. A few days later, I called to check on the status of my credit card application. It turns out I was approved for a credit line, but couldn't get the card yet because I didn't have a bank account at Andrews. Apparently, their bank account and credit card departments were separate.
    5. So I filled out the bank account online application and provided them with my ACC membership number. (I highly recommend doing this step first.)
    6. Soon afterwards, Andrews' credit card department called me and let me know that they were sending me some electronic documents to sign.
    7. About a week later, I got my debit and GlobeTrek VISA cards in the mail, along with two PIN numbers. Although it didn't say so on the papers, one PIN was for my debit card and the other was for use with the chip-and-pin feature of my credit card. I had to try each pin with my debit card at a co-op ATM in order to figure out which was which.
    8. I then had to mail a physical copy of my membership application along with a signature card (provided as a PDF during the application process) to Andrews.
    9. Finally, in order to allow phone support to help me in case I got stuck somewhere, I had to send in a security password notification form to set up my security phrase.
    You can find more discussion in this FlyerTalk thread. ↩
  5. Among the problems:
    • Paying off your credit card is a bit of a mysterious process. There are apparently two places you can do this: your Andrews SmartConnect account, and a separate service called VISA Online. If you go to the Andrews website, there's a stand-alone account called "VISA" your Andrews , along with your checking and savings accounts, there's also a stand-alone account called "VISA". This account looks like your other accounts, but it can only accept transfers into it, not out. Once you've put your money in, it stays there until your credit card statement is due, at which point it's whisked away to pay off the balance. Weird.
    • Andrews has at least two different phone numbers and addresses for each department. I imagine this has to do with them contracting out some of their services. Nonetheless, it makes it hard to tell who to call and where to send stuff.
    • Credit union co-op ATMs aren't very reliable or user-friendly. Oftentimes, they'll get to the deposit/withdrawal screen, but then fail mysteriously when you try to do something. They'll do this even if you enter the wrong PIN. It's also a pain to deposit cash into your account. You can't do it via most ATMs (the one exception is [], which only accepts checks), so you have to use physical co-op branches.
